competitive_positioning.investor_access: Requires planned trips to Cambridge/Boston for VC meetings; less walk-in investor traffic
competitive_positioning.customer_proximity: Close to defense contractors and logistics hubs along Route 128/I-95 corridor
competitive_positioning.regulatory_advantages: Flexible zoning for light industrial, R&D, and drone testing; fewer urban airspace restrictions

growth_trajectory.expansion_opportunities: Ample adjacent office/lab space in Burlington tech parks; scalable for hardware prototyping and drone testing
growth_trajectory.infrastructure_constraints: Limited public transit; car dependency may hinder some talent attraction; less urban vibrancy
growth_trajectory.planned_developments: Ongoing upgrades to Route 128 corridor, new mixed-use developments, and potential MBTA bus rapid transit improvements

spatialInsights.clustering_pattern: Enigma Aerospace chose Burlington for its concentration of aerospace/robotics firms, affordable R&D space, and proximity to major highways and defense customers, rather than dense urban startup clusters
geographic_advantages: Lower real estate costs and flexible zoning for hardware/flight testing
Proximity to Route 128/I-95 tech corridor and major defense contractors
Access to MIT/Harvard/Northeastern talent within a 20-minute drive
geographic_risks: Weaker spontaneous networking compared to Cambridge/Boston
Limited public transit may restrict access for some talent
Potential isolation from VC and startup ecosystem events
spatialInsights.ecosystem_positioning: Burlington positions Enigma Aerospace at the intersection of Boston‚Äôs deep tech R&D and the Route 128 defense/robotics cluster, enabling hardware innovation and defense partnerships but requiring deliberate engagement with urban VC and academic networks
